setup.question: What is likely the next step in the story?
answers: Bob and Quezy work with Starre to come up with a solution to both their problems,
Bob and Quezy deliver the asteroid, and Starre marries Mac.

Text.text: I have a feeling B will be true insofar as the evidence is explicit, that is I see a proof of evidence with the asteroid and a proof of evidence with the marriage. A is a bit more vague. Otherwise I would appreciate a quick story summary of what is happening before either of you get into the convincing part. Have fun :D
Bob and Quezy are trying to purchase an asteroid on behalf of Starre's grandfather,
who has been

, Starre says. An enemy business is also trying to buy the asteroid and Starre is initially attempting to fight off both teams so that she does not have to get married (the condition being that she would get married on the purchased asteroid). However, as the enemy team proves themselves very strong, they decide
and that
, the other problem being Starre's marriage to Mac. Bob then falls in love with Starre and at the end,
and the natural next step would definitely not be for Starre to marry Mac.

The story starts with Bob and Quezy, two spacemen who are looking to deliver a specific asteroid for a billionaire's daughter's wedding. They find it and are about to move it, but they find that someone else, Starre, has claimed it as her own. The two spacemen are about to leave before they're attacked by a rival group of asteroid prospectors, who steal the asteroid. Bob, Quezy, and Starre go to chase them, eventually taking back the asteroid in a space battle.

Bob and Quezy need the asteroid because they'll be rich if they acquire it. When they find it, Bob says "

"

Mac is Starre's fiance:
Can expand in next speech.

B mentions the fiance claim, but that doesn't actually mean marriage. I think its easier as the judge to resolve it from the angle of whether B is right or not since its a straight up fact. I'll give it another round to see if B really has a marriage piece of evidence in their pocket, or if the next speech claim was just to buy time. I am skeptical because if it really was the case you would've found a very simple quote to prove it. Additionally, A makes compelling points about the marriage ONTOP of explaining the whole idea of the problem being solved, which is pretty much what A's prompt is on about.

Since B hasn't really provided anything worth refuting, I'll begin by reiterating what I've already explained. Bob and Quezy fought a rival business to deliver the asteroid to Mr. Burnside, Starre's grandfather. While working with Starre to solve both of their problems, they defeat the rival team. The logical next step, considering the fact that Starre does not want to get married and Bob is in love with Starre, would not be to use their victory in order to marry Starre off to Mac; it would be, as their plan already was, to solve both of their problems by working as a team. B has not proven, in any way, to the contrary, and it's very obvious that A should stand.
B's quote is out of context, here's what Bob says before:

Super blatant lie, very sus

On the marriage, Bob asks Starre:

, because she made an agreement with her grandfather that if he found a specific asteroid to marry her on, she'd agree, more ev can be provided I just needed to point out the lie in the last quote. 

The only ev for the three working together is a quote taken way out of context. Bob says he has to deliver the asteroid, that's for his payment, and Starre says she has to marry Mac.

would vote if A has an evidence for Bob falling in love with Starre, and starre reciprocating that love. Im pretty close to voting A here anyway since B just won't cough up ev about the marriage actually happening but just to be safe and provide a 99-1 here.

is from when Bob begins to fall in love with Starre, and though they do have a bit of an enemies-to-lovers thing in that they *initially* have conflicting interests (which is what B misconstrued in their last speech) the story ends in victory, which means no forced marriage to Mac for Starre.

A quote that sumrz everything but it's too long so I'll fill in gaps: Bob trying to confess his love
She replies
bc though she loves Bob at this point she's scared of losing, so can't reciprocate. Ofc, tho, they win in the end.
Idk how much more ev you want judge, here's some more lines from the story:
. That's from Starre directly.

That's the original order from Burnside, bc he wants to get his daughter married. I have way more evidence from every party involved that the marriage is going to happen, just because Bob and Starre love each other isn't going to stop a millionaire from buying out their company. 

B's evidence doesn't prove anything, there's no definitive ev for Starre loving Bob, it's all extrapolation.

Hope to vote after this round: just need evidence for the delivery. Did the asteroid get delivered? If B can prove this round will extend itself, if not ill vote for A. Just wanna be extra safe here in case I'm letting the fact that A went first influence my judgement.
Bob and Quezy, because of Bob's love for Starre, changed their minds about delivering the asteroid; therefore, all they had to do was stop their rivals, the Saylors from delivering it
which they do:
. As I mentioned,

--i.e. no, judge, the asteroid was not delivered in the end.  Starre's entire reason for being on the asteroid in the first place was to try to thwart her grandfather's purchase of it so that she didn't have to marry Mac; why would she do so if she and the man she loves were victorious in the end? I don't really think I need to give more evidence than that.
bruh

B seems to have largely conceded by this point and as I reviewed all the evidence in the quotes tab I see nothing to suggest the marriage happened nor the asteroid being delivered. I think A could've explained the problem a bit better, but B giving up made this a 99-1.
....listened to inroom convo, leaning A bc it seems that they don't get married
Yeah, no clear ev for a wedding, and the fact that Bob falls in love with Starre probably disproves B.

answers.other factors: Anuj + Sean's argument about this was very important...
answers.reason for outcome: In room convo solidified my doubts about B. Thanks Sean + Anuj. I realize this is against the spirit of debate but...
Quality of evidence and the judge is just an absolute champ
